185215160.review:
Bastante Entretenido 

-La Historia es buena ya que es algo diferente de que hay que acomodar las lineas del tiempo para que pasen las cosas como deberian de pasar y no se estorcionen , es algo diferente que necesitaban sus juegos para no siempre ser lo mismo. 

-La Jugabilidad en un principio me preocupaba porque lo iba a jugar con teclado y pensaba que los controles ivan a ser muy toscos pero nop , son comodos y no tan toscos y te acostumbras rapido.

-La Optimizacion del juego considero que es una cosa que deberia de mencionarse , ya que es algo que se agradece infinitamente para jugadores con computadoras no tan potentes , y considero que el juego esta bien optimizado , tampoco esperes que el juego funcione en una computadora tan tan baja en recursos.

-El Contenido del juego es una de las cosas mas buenas , ya que tiene muchas misiones secundarias y las misiones principales estan buenas.

-Avanzamientos del juego , el como avanzas y vas evolucionando tu personaje poco a poco es algo que considero muy bueno y bien logrado en este juego.

No e tenido bugs ni crasheos ni caidas de rendimiento en ningun momento.

EN GENERAL : Esta Bastante entretenido el juego , no es un juego asi que tu digas que te cambie la vida pero esta bastante entretenido y si eres fan de DBZ pues lo disfrutaras aun mejor, Bastante Recomendable 

PD:Las salas multijugador  aveces funcionan y aveces no pero si hay gente jugando

184740808.review:
Dragon Ball Xenoverse is a fantastic game that successfully combines the best elements of the Dragon Ball universe with engaging gameplay mechanics. The ability to create and customize your own fighter is a standout feature, allowing players to choose from a variety of races, each with unique stats and fighting styles. The game's story mode revisits iconic moments from the Dragon Ball Z series, adding a fresh twist and allowing players to play a pivotal role in these battles.

The combat system is fast-paced and exciting, capturing the spectacle and intensity of DBZ fights. The addition of online multiplayer modes adds to the fun, letting you team up with friends or other players to take on challenging missions and engage in epic battles. The game also includes a variety of side quests and customization options, making it a rich and immersive experience for fans of the series.

Overall, Dragon Ball Xenoverse offers a great mix of nostalgia and new content, making it a must-play for any Dragon Ball fan.

184488800.review:
Jogabilidade
A jogabilidade de Dragon Ball Xenoverse é uma combinação de mecânicas tradicionais de jogos de luta 3D com elementos de RPG. Os jogadores controlam um personagem personalizado, conhecido como "Viajante do Tempo", e podem escolher entre diferentes raças, como Saiyajin, Namekuseijin, Majin, entre outras. Cada raça tem atributos e habilidades distintas, o que proporciona uma experiência variada a cada jogada.

Os combates acontecem em arenas tridimensionais, o que permite movimentação livre no espaço. A jogabilidade é bastante dinâmica, com ataques rápidos, combos e poderosos ataques especiais, características típicas dos jogos da franquia. No entanto, Xenoverse se diferencia pela possibilidade de personalização e evolução do personagem. O jogador pode aumentar atributos como força, velocidade e resistência, além de adquirir novas habilidades e ataques, o que proporciona uma sensação de progressão e crescimento.

Além disso, o jogo inclui uma série de missões secundárias e desafios que permitem ao jogador desbloquear novos personagens e equipamentos, oferecendo uma boa dose de replayability. A mecânica de jogo é bem balanceada, sendo acessível tanto para iniciantes quanto para jogadores mais experientes da série.

Gráficos e Design
Em termos de gráficos, Dragon Ball Xenoverse apresenta uma boa reprodução do estilo visual da série animada, com modelos 3D que imitam as versões dos personagens no anime. Os cenários são detalhados e recriam com precisão locais icônicos de Dragon Ball, como a Terra e o Templo de Kami. No entanto, em comparação com outros jogos lançados na mesma época, os gráficos de Xenoverse podem parecer um pouco aquém em termos de detalhes e texturas, especialmente nas versões de consoles da geração anterior, como PlayStation 3 e Xbox 360.

A direção de arte é, de forma geral, eficaz em capturar a essência de Dragon Ball, mantendo o estilo visual que os fãs esperam. As animações de combate também são satisfatórias, com ataques especiais e "final blows" que lembram momentos emblemáticos da série.

Trilha Sonora e Áudio
A trilha sonora de Dragon Ball Xenoverse é composta por uma mistura de músicas originais e faixas clássicas da série Dragon Ball Z, além de efeitos sonoros típicos dos jogos de luta. A música de fundo durante os combates é empolgante e se encaixa bem com o ritmo frenético da ação. As músicas também ajudam a reforçar a imersão, especialmente durante as batalhas mais intensas.

O áudio dos personagens é outro ponto positivo, com as vozes originais dos dubladores da série, que adicionam autenticidade e familiaridade para os fãs. As falas dos personagens durante os combates são satisfatórias, embora, em alguns momentos, possam parecer repetitivas.

Recepção Crítica
A recepção crítica de Dragon Ball Xenoverse foi geralmente positiva, com os críticos elogiando o conceito inovador de viagem no tempo e a possibilidade de personalização dos personagens. A diversidade de raças jogáveis e a adaptação da história de Dragon Ball para incluir eventos alternativos também foram bem recebidas.

Por outro lado, algumas críticas foram direcionadas ao sistema de combate, que, embora divertido, foi considerado superficial por alguns jogadores mais exigentes com jogos de luta. O design gráfico, como mencionado, também recebeu comentários mistos, sendo considerado bom, mas sem grandes inovações em relação aos padrões da época. No entanto, a jogabilidade e o conteúdo expansivo ajudaram a equilibrar essas falhas.

Conclusão
Dragon Ball Xenoverse é uma tentativa bem-sucedida de inovar a fórmula dos jogos de luta de Dragon Ball, trazendo elementos de RPG e um enredo envolvente com viagens no tempo. A combinação de personalização do personagem, combates intensos e uma narrativa que revisita os momentos mais icônicos da série faz com que o jogo seja um prato cheio para os fãs de longa data e também para os novos jogadores.

Embora existam algumas limitações em termos gráficos e de profundidade no combate, Xenoverse oferece uma experiência sólida e divertida, garantindo seu lugar como um dos títulos mais interessantes da franquia. O sucesso do jogo também gerou sequências, como Dragon Ball Xenoverse 2, que aprimoram muitos dos elementos aqui apresentados. Para os fãs de Dragon Ball e dos jogos de luta em geral, Xenoverse é uma escolha recomendada.

183851116.review:
Okay, I have a lot to say about this game. However, I will start by saying that I love this game, my playtime should speak to that. But I cannot recommend it in good conscience, for a variety of reasons. Chief of which are that it  is an online game with a low player count nowadays, and that you can get all of this game's content within its sequel for less than just buying this game.
Now, to get to my review proper. This is written from the perspective of someone who has completed this game in every sense of the word. Yes, I spent hundreds of hours grinding Parallel Quests to obtain everything in the game.

My perspective on this game has shifted a lot over the amount of time I have sunken into it. I started off full of nostalgia for the game I played way back at release, then I went to a slightly harsher view, and finally to acknowledging that, though I love this game, it does not respect the player or their time. I'll break this down into a few sections, and go over what I like, and why I think this game actively fights the player for wanting to enjoy it.

Section one, the game play. This is the game's strongest point, never once did I stop enjoying this. I am not very big into fighting games, I'm just not good at them, but this one I enjoy a lot. It's simple, easy to pick up, a whole lot of fun. My only real complaints are the fact that you can't see your opponent's stamina or Ki, and thus can't make informed decisions based on them, and an issue I'll expand on in section two. This is a simple arena fighter, and occasionally a beat-em-up. You have a few methods of attack; weak attack, strong attack, ki blasts, evasive skills, and Super/Ultimate attacks. To use super/ultimate attacks, you have to have a corresponding amount of Ki, being 100 (equal to one visual bar) and 300 respectively, and to use evasive skills, you have to have 300 stamina. Additionally, you can vanish by timing a button press with an opponent's attack, or you can block incoming attacks. There are a few issues I have with the special attacks, but to go into them, I'll need a bit more context. There are several different types of attacks in the game, Strike, Energy, Power-up, transformation and other. Strike attacks, in my opinion, are difficult to land and rarely give enough damage to be worth that lack in range. Energy attacks feel random at times, and because some are nearly identical to each other, finding the best ones can be quite the difficult task. Power-up moves are rarely worth even thinking about as they leave you wide open for at least a second or two for buffs that sometimes hardly last 10 seconds. Tranformation skills have a unique problem, in that out of the 8 total options, (7 in the base game), a whopping 4 of them can only be used by Saiyans, and on top of that, those 4 are the best ones in the game. Other type skills are a mixed bag, but they do contain the only way to charge Ki without attacking or being attacked. No full set of skills is without its odd issues.

Section two, Difficulty balancing. This is just bad, there is no way around that. The game feels like it was balanced entirely around Saiyans, because they have the absolutely broken ability to spam ultimate attacks for as long as they have ki and stamina as soon as they get access to the first of 4 different Super Saiyan skills. This overpowered ability means that if the game wants to have any challenge to the myriad of people that pick Saiyan because this is a dragon ball game, they have to over tune the difficulty as any other race. There are some missions that borderline require the ability that Saiyans have to lock down enemies, as they want you to protect characters that have very little health. I tried to play as a Majin for a bit, after unlocking the ONLY Ultimate attack transformation that non-Saiyans can use, and I found that one such mission was prohibitively difficult when I was unable to keep pressure on one enemy indefinitely. That is a harsh strike against this game, but not as harsh as...

Section Three, RNG. This game is absolutely plagued with RNG, and it takes thing from fun to frustrating VERY quickly. The game's content is mostly held within the 67 (66 not counting the tutorial, 55 not counting DLC) Parallel Quests, and these are where all of the RNG is held. Practically everything in these horrible things is RNG. Skill drops, clothing drops, accessory drops, and even whether you get to go to the end of the mission are all random. Every mission has what is called an "Ultimate Finish" in which enemies will get up, or new enemies will spawn after the end of a mission. To access these sections, you must meet certain conditions while playing the mission. This is fine by itself, a cool idea even. However, it is not fine that even if you fulfill these requirements, there's a good chance the mission will simply act like you didn't. Worse yet, the game doesn't even give you the courtesy of telling you what the conditions even are until you have successfully triggered them AND the game decides to allow passage into these sections. This would be bad enough even if some of the conditions weren't odd and overly specific, like one relatively early mission where you have to leave an area mid battle, find and recruit an ally, who is the only one in the game who will join you on speaking to them, and then return to the battle, and let that new ally die. And even then, after all that, there is a good chance the game will bar you from the Ultimate Finish portion of the mission. And if that weren't bad enough, there are many, MANY drops throughout the game with abysmal drop rates that can only be accessed WITHIN these section that have RNG just to get to. Grinding this game to full completion to a toll on me because of the sheer amount of random elements.

In conclusion, I cannot recommend this game both because it is outdated, and, though I love it, it would sooner spit in the player's face with awful RNG than actually respect them and their time.
